awd_titl_txt: Parameterizing sub-grid Arctic snow-on-sea-ice processes in Earth System Models using MOSAiC field observations and realistic-resolution process models.
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will help answer one of the key questions being asked by the international Arctic climate-science community: What is the role of snow-on-sea-ice in controlling heat exchanges in the Arctic climate system? This work will educate young scientists in the combined issues of field measurements, high-resolution modeling, and representing high-resolution processes in regional and global models. In addition, it will collect high quality field measurements that will advance Arctic system science for years to come.
  
This research will synthesize three interrelated science contributions: (1) Multidisciplinary drifting Observatory for the Study of Arctic Climate (MOSAiC) field observations will identify governing physical processes, fluxes, and linkages within the Arctic climate system. (2) Realistic-resolution (meters-scale), physically based modeling tools (e.g., MicroMet, SnowModel, EnBal, SnowPack, SnowTran-3D, SnowDunes, SnowAssim, SeaIce-3D) will quantify the behavior, interactions, and sensitivities among the Arctic system components. (3) Field observations and high-resolution modeling will be integrated to define what is missing or poorly represented in Earth System Models and guide the parameterization of the associated snow-related processes and fluxes for the Community Earth System Model (CESM) and the Los Alamos Sea Ice Model (CICE).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In previous studies, snow-on-sea-ice and its controls on heat fluxes between the Arctic Ocean and the atmosphere were identified as critical weaknesses in our understanding and ability to model Earth’s climate. In addition, the associated mechanisms are all thought to be high-resolution, sub-grid processes that require parameterization within the current and next generation of Earth System Models in order to appropriately account for them in our climate projections. This project helped answer a key question currently being asked by the international Arctic climate-science community: What is the role of snow-on-sea-ice in controlling heat fluxes in the Arctic climate system?

This question was answered by merging three interrelated science contributions: 1) Multidisciplinary drifting Observatory for the Study of Arctic Climate (MOSAiC) field observations identified governing physical processes, fluxes, and linkages within the Arctic climate system. 2) Realistic-resolution (meters-scale), physically based modeling tools (e.g., MicroMet, SnowModel, EnBal, SnowPack, SnowTran-3D, SnowDunes, SnowAssim, SeaIce-3D) quantified the behavior, interactions, and sensitivities among the Arctic system components. 3) The synthesis of field observations and high-resolution modeling defined what is missing or poorly represented in Earth System Models and were used to support parameterizations of the associated snow-related processes and fluxes in Earth System Models.

This project combining field observations and modeling tools to helped create, improve, and implement a collection of state-of-the-art, high-resolution, physics-based, snow and ice evolution modeling tools. These were merged with detailed field observation datasets describing the evolution of snow distribution and thermal conductivity on sea ice, as well as the attendant impacts on ice growth and ocean-ice-snow-atmosphere energy exchanges. The data synthesis and model validation performed by this project resulted in, for example, substantial improvement in the representation of snow thermal conductivity on sea ice in predictive models. This, in turn, will improve the physical realism in predictive models describing sea ice and Arctic and global climate.
